cards.front: State the formal definition of a periodic signal.
cards.back: x(t) = x(t + mT₀) for all integers m and some positive T₀. The smallest such T₀ is the fundamental period.

cards.front: How are T₀, f₀, and ω₀ related?
cards.back: f₀ = 1/T₀ (Hz) and ω₀ = 2π/T₀ = 2πf₀ (rad/s). T₀ is the fundamental period, f₀ the fundamental frequency, ω₀ the angular fundamental frequency.

cards.front: How do you find the fundamental period of a sum of sinusoids?
cards.back: T₀ = LCM of the individual periods. Equivalently, ω₀ = GCD of all component angular frequencies. The ratio of any two frequencies must be rational for the signal to be periodic.

cards.front: Write sin(θ) and cos(θ) in terms of complex exponentials.
cards.back:
sin(θ) = (e^{jθ} − e^{−jθ}) / (2j)
cos(θ) = (e^{jθ} + e^{−jθ}) / 2
These are inverse Euler formulas, essential for converting to the EFS.

cards.front: What is the DC component X₀ of a periodic signal?
cards.back: X₀ = (1/T₀) ∫_{T₀} x(t) dt — the average value of x(t) over one period. It is a real number for real signals.

cards.front: What does the magnitude spectrum |X_k| represent?
cards.back: |X_k| gives the amplitude of the k-th harmonic component. Together with the phase spectrum ∠X_k, it uniquely determines the periodic signal.

cards.front: Why are periodic signals called power signals?
cards.back: They repeat forever → infinite energy. But their average power P = (1/T₀)∫_{T₀} |x(t)|² dt is finite. So they are power signals, not energy signals.

cards.front: What is the key idea of inter-domain analysis?
cards.back: The same signal has multiple equivalent representations on different axes (domains). In the time domain it is x(t); in the Fourier domain it is the set of coefficients X_k. Neither is more 'real' — they are two views of the same object.

cards.front: When is a sum x(t) = sin(ω₁t) + sin(ω₂t) NOT periodic?
cards.back: When ω₁/ω₂ is irrational. There is no common period if the ratio of frequencies is not a rational number. Example: sin(πt) + sin(√2·t) is not periodic.

cards.front: What are X₁, X₂, X₃ called in the Fourier Series?
cards.back: X₁ = fundamental component (at ω₀), X₂ = 2nd harmonic (at 2ω₀), X₃ = 3rd harmonic (at 3ω₀). Higher harmonics carry finer signal detail and have diminishing magnitudes.
